results.title: Nursing is tough
results.creator_credit: Helen Gaynor, Ivo Burum, ABC-TV (Australia) and Alfred Hospital
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Nurses”.
‘Nurses’ “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 1. Introduction to the nurses, their fields of specialisation, views and experiences. Deals with what attracted the women to nursing in the first place and how their experience has differed from initial expectations. Examines the stereotype of nursing as ‘nice girls’ occupation proposing instead that nursing and by extension nurses are tough. Jane talks about emergency as an experience that brings you face to face with the fundamentals of life and death. Cassie speaks about her foray into nursing as something unfortunately rare for a woman brought up in the western suburbs. Kerryn talks about the sense that it was only in her third year as a registered nurse that the ‘big picture’ of what nursing demands hit her. And Trish articulates the mixed feelings involved in working with homeless psychiatric patients, of “having to force people to do something they don’t want to do, but knowing that if you don’t they end up in pain, vulnerable and traumatised”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Helen Gaynor, Ivo Burum, ABC-TV (Australia) and Alfred Hospital

results.title: Nurses
results.creator_credit: Helen Gaynor, Ivo Burum, ABC-TV (Australia) and Alfred Hospital
results.brief_description: This is real reality TV. A four part series filmed by four nurses at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne, Nurses demysitifys the soap opera version of hospital practice that usually dominates TV -and it makes for dramatic viewing. A documentary that is also a commitment to egalitarian film-making, Nurses is a real life drama brought into being through the varied experiences and above all narrative ability of its four makers and subjects. From Jane Newham in Emergency, and Cassie Steward in Theatre we get all the immediacy, fast paced excitment and yes, blood and gore of critical medicine and from Kerryn O’Rourke in oncology and Psychiatric Nurse to the homeless, Trish Builic, we see the ongoing patient relationships and responsibilities that are just as much a part of nurseing as the medical administration. Ultimately however the distinctions don’t remain that clear and it is the finely nuanced political and personal concerns combined with the passion and depth of feeling of the women that really makes this series. The espisodic breakdown is gathered under four headings; Episode 1 “Nurses are Tough” introduces us to the women and their hospital setting. Episode 2 “Work Around the Clock” brings us further into the women’s personal lives and how they cope with the 24 hour 7 day a week work schedual. Episode 3 “Coping with Death” explores the coping mechanisms nurses employ in a job that brings them face to face with mortality daily. Episode 4 “Is there life after Death?” questions wether the historical alignement of nurseing and spirituality are still a contemporary motivation or is does it inspire and appeal moreso to a secular humanitarianism. Nurses is not afraid of emphasising that in this profession the personal is the political. There is political undercurrent to the series and it engages sensitivly with institutional issues such the state of the Australian healthcare system, nurseing burn out rates, hospital heriarchies - particularly the status of Nurses compared to Doctors and the old saying “overworked and underpaid”. It also subtly but decidedly examines wider community concerns such as the workability of community care and issues surrounding drug abuse and community attitudes to mental health. Facts and Figures. Courtesy ABC website: 2 years in development, 127 hours of original footage shot between Oct. 1999 and Jan 2000. 1-3 person crews, including nurse, with Helen Gaynor providing directorial support.

results.title: Is there life after death?
results.creator_credit: Helen Gaynor, Ivo Burum, ABC-TV (Australia) and Alfred Hospital
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Nurses”.
Nurses “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 4. With Christmas and the Millenium coming up there are conclusions and last comments. There are holidays taken, shopping to be done and religion and beliefs are reflected upon. Jane demystifies the bed pan. One of Kerryn’s patients has rapidly deteriorated. Cassie becomes a patient. And Trish gets frustrated at the outpouring of good will on Christmas day and wonders where it all goes for the rest of the year.

results.title: Coping with death
results.creator_credit: Helen Gaynor, Ivo Burum, ABC-TV (Australia) and Alfred Hospital
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Nurses”.
Nurses “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 3: This episode examines the kind of thoughts and coping mechanisms the nurses have developed in a job that obviously has a high mortality rate. And in particular reflects upon the naivete of the ‘I am going to be a nurse to help people’ idea that all four women have had to deal with. This episode elaborates upon a patient relationship that we have already seen Kerryn commit to. She talks about the way she has necessarily become more detached and that some days, especially with staff shortages the physical side of nursing of observing patients and administering medication means that you just don’t have the ability to feel sad. And that the flip side to this is that ultimately patients appreciate the kindness, understanding and sensitivity given by nurses not if they got their medication on time. Trish talks about the sense of emotions being at either end of the spectrum, that when someone commits suicide or an assault occurs it’s a big jolt in reminding her how crucial the job is. Jane talks about the ‘controlled voice’ she finds herself using when something really serious is happening.

results.title: Coping with conflict
results.creator_credit: Ron Tanner, David Evans and Millbank Films
results.brief_description: A conflict situation is dramatised within a small textile finishing works. Steps taken to resolving it are shown. A fruitful discussion starter, it presents lessons from the conflicts in the film to the audience and additional skills learned along the way.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ron Tanner, David Evans and Millbank Films

results.title: Cop it sweet
results.brief_description: In 1991 an ABC film crew spent six weeks following the police in Redfern, a suburb of Sydney - a predominantly working class area with a large Aboriginal and migrant population. The police in this documentary are general duty officers mainly on mobile patrols in the Redfern area. This reveals police attitudes and shows how they deal with people of different ethnic backgrounds and a range of offences.

results.title: Cool runnings
results.creator_credit: Jon Turteltaub, Dawn Steel and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: The world was shocked when Jamaica entered the Winter Olympics with a bobsled team. Although they don’t win gold, the four Jamaicans become heroes for their courage and determination to compete with the world’s best. John Candy plays the ex-Olympian, once accused of cheating, who acts as their coach. Based on a true story “Cool Runnings” repeats the ageless Disney film message about following your dreams.

results.title: Cooking Jewish with Penny Harris
results.creator_credit: Lucille Rogers, Penny Harris, Shalom Gery and Cooking Jewish Productions
results.brief_description: Passed down from generation to generation, traditional cooking has always been at the centre of Jewish life. In this video we are introduced to the simple delights of Eastern European Jewish cuisine by cooking teacher Penny Harris. Penny will demonstrate the preparation of a dozen dishes and share some of the cultural background of the recipes, which include: chopped liver ; Russian herring salad ; pickled cucumbers ; gefilte fish ; fried fish ; chicken soup ; potato latkes ; Tsimmes ; Klops ; Cholent ; veal brisket and cheese blintzes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lucille Rogers, Penny Harris, Shalom Gery and Cooking Jewish Productions

results.title: Convicted
results.creator_credit: Kay Pavlou, Mike Piper and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: 5% of prisoners in Australian prisons are women. 85% of these are in prison for drug-related crimes. In this film the women of Northfield Prison Complex in South Australia, prisoners, warders, psychologists, recount their experiences. The specific problems of women - the care of children, familial attitudes, low self-esteem are highlighted as is the lack of rehabilitation which leads to 65% recidivism.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kay Pavlou, Mike Piper and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: Conversations with a dead poet: Alan Wearne recalls John Forbes [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Geoff Burton, John Izzard, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Seedwillow
results.brief_description: Alan Wearne, poet and tutor hosts this documentary about his friend and colleague John Forbes (1950-98), one of Australia’s most prominent modern poets with his distinctly gritty writing about urban Melbourne and Sydney. Drawing on extracts from several of Forbes’ poems, and discussions with friends and devotees of his writing, the following works are explored in detail: “Tropical skiing”; “On the beach”; “Stalin’s holidays”; “The Stunned mullet”; “Damaged glamour”.
results.title_for_label: Conversations with a dead poet: Alan Wearne recalls John Forbes [Widescreen]
